creator: wsmwk

content:
Have you checked in account settings that Thunderbird should be checking for new messages on startup? This is a per account setting in server settings.

Go to Connection settings These can be found in setting by searching connection and clicking the "settings" button. The default is no proxy I would also encourage you to enable DNS over HTTPS for your own security if it is not already enabled. That will mean DNS resolution will be undertaken with cloudflare by default 

https://www.cloudflare.com/en-au/application-services/products/dns/

It will also mean hat your DNS requests are encrypted and not passed around in plain text but a more complete lay discussion of this is at Wikipedia https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DNS_over_HTTPS
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Yes, that box is checked, and it seems to check for new messages on startup without any problem. However, it does not check for new incoming mail after startup, which makes the product useless to me.

creator: nerpielsen

content:
You control how long mail is retained.

In Thunderbird: account settings > synchronization & storage.

I have mine set never to delete messages.

There are also folder-level settings in Thunderbird that override the account settings: right click on a folder > properties > retention policy

You may also have some settings at the server that you can access through webmail. My server has an auto-purge setting for the spam and trash folders.
creator: mozilla98

content: You certainly have activated the Quick Filter. Quick Filter is disables in trouble shoot mode. To disable it in normal mode just click on the Quick Filter button in the tool bar
